Think about how knowing the mean value may be helpful in terms of solving for any unknown parameters.

question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
We recall that the probability density function (PDF) for an exponential random variable is given by

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \begin{cases} \lambda e^{-\lambda x} &\mbox{if}\, x \ge 0\\ 0 &\mbox{otherwise} \end{cases},\quad \lambda > 0.\end{aligned}\]

The probability that \(X\) is greater than or equal to 8 is given by integrating the PDF from \(x = 8\) to infinity.

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}[X \ge 8] = \int_{8}^{\infty}f(x)\,dx = \lambda\int_8^\infty{}e^{-\lambda x}\textrm{d}x=-e^{-\lambda x}\Big\vert_{8}^{\infty} = e^{-8\lambda}\end{aligned}\]

Clearly, we need the value of \(\lambda\) if we are to evaluate the probability that \(X\) is greater than or equal to 8. We can determine this by evaluating the mean of \(f(x)\) and comparing to the given value. The mean of \(f(x)\) is

\[\begin{aligned} &\lambda\underbrace{\int_0^\infty{}xe^{-\lambda x}\textrm{d}x}_{\text{integrate by parts}}\\ &=\left.-xe^{-\lambda x}\right|_0^\infty+\int_0^\infty{}e^{-\lambda x}=\frac{1}{\lambda}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore the mean of \(f(x)\) is \(\lambda^{-1} = 4\), and thus \(\lambda = 1/4\). Plugging this into the result above, we find that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \mathbb{P}[X \ge 8] = e^{-2} \quad(\approx 0.1353).\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
A continuous random variable \(\displaystyle X\) is exponentially distributed with a mean of \(4\).

Find the probability that \(X \geq 8\).
